headline.main: Aetna Agrees to Buy Coventry in $5.7 Billion Deal
headline.print_headline: Aetna Agrees to Buy Rival In Deal Worth $5.7 Billion

docs.abstract: The acquisition, which gives Aetna a larger share of Medicare and Medicaid, would be the biggest in the managed health care industry since the Affordable Care Act was signed into law in 2010.
docs.snippet: The acquisition, which gives Aetna a larger share of Medicare and Medicaid, would be the biggest in the managed health care industry since the Affordable Care Act was signed into law in 2010.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED

docs.abstract: In New Hampshire, voters - whether it's a hotel housekeeper or the speaker of the House - hold nothing back.
docs.snippet: In New Hampshire, voters - whether it's a hotel housekeeper or the speaker of the House - hold nothing back.

docs.lead_paragraph: Apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen — and can be reimbursed by insurance — will soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients.

headline.seo: Coming Next: Doctors Prescribing Apps to Patients
headline.main: Coming Next: Using an App as Prescribed
headline.print_headline: Coming Next: Using an App As Prescribed

docs.abstract: Smartphone apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen, and can be reimbursed by insurance, may soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients; idea excites some health care professionals, but first issues around vetting, paying for and monitoring the use of such apps need to be worked out.
docs.snippet: Apps that can assess data like blood glucose levels, diet and drug regimen — and can be reimbursed by insurance — will soon be prescribed by doctors to help treat patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: The truth is that for a large part of medical practice, we don’t know what works. But we pay for it anyway.

headline.main: Testing What We Think We Know
headline.print_headline: Testing What We Think We Know

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by professor of medicine H Gilbert Welch underscores the amount of uncertainty that exists about the effectiveness of a large part of medical practices; calls for more medical research focused on evaluating standard treatments.
docs.snippet: The truth is that for a large part of medical practice, we don’t know what works. But we pay for it anyway.

docs.lead_paragraph: The couple were married by a justice of the Supreme Court.
docs.snippet: The couple were married by a justice of the Supreme Court.

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget writers have been finding ways to promise voters more programs and services without increasing taxes, but in early 2013 their luck may run out.

headline.seo: Texas Budget Writers Find Ways to Keep Conflicting Promises
headline.main: Sneaky Ways to Keep Conflicting Promises
headline.print_headline: Sneaky Ways to Keep Conflicting Promises

docs.snippet: The budget writers have been finding ways to promise voters more programs and services without increasing taxes, but in early 2013 their luck may run out.

docs.lead_paragraph: The number of practicing psychologists in Argentina has been surging, making the country a world leader, at least when it comes to people’s broad willingness to bare their souls.

headline.seo: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch
headline.main: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch
headline.print_headline: Do Argentines Need Therapy? Pull Up a Couch

docs.abstract: Number of practicing psychologists in Argentina has been surging, making the country a world leader, at least when it comes to its people's broad willingness to bare their souls; theories abound as to why psychological hang-ups seem to be so prolific in the country.
docs.snippet: The number of practicing psychologists in Argentina has been surging, making the country a world leader, at least when it comes to people’s broad willingness to bare their souls.

docs.lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan spoke of his care for a relative with Alzheimer’s, seeking to counter President Obama’s charge that Republicans would “end Medicare as we know it.”

headline.seo: Romney and Obama Campaigns Seize Role of Medicare Defender
headline.main: Both Campaigns Seize Role of Medicare Defender
headline.print_headline: Both Campaigns Seize Role of Medicare Defender

docs.abstract: Republican vice presidential candidate Paul D Ryan campaigns at The Villages, Fla, seeking to play offense on Medicare by attacking in detail Pres Obama's health care plan; Pres Obama, campaigning in New Hampshire, dismisses the Romney campaign's tactics on Medicare, saying it is Mitt Romney and Ryan who threaten the program.
docs.snippet: Paul Ryan spoke of his care for a relative with Alzheimer’s, seeking to counter President Obama’s charge that Republicans would “end Medicare as we know it.”

byline.contributor: Trip Gabriel reported from The Villages, Fla., and Helene Cooper from Windham, N.H.
byline.original: By TRIP GABRIEL and HELENE COOPER

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder has sought to fix his state’s economy and avoid party-line battles, but in an increasingly partisan era, is that enough?

headline.seo: Rick Snyder, a G.O.P. Governor Who Eludes Labels
headline.main: Michigan’s G.O.P. Governor Defies Easy Labels
headline.print_headline: Michigan’s G.O.P. Governor Defies Easy Labels

docs.abstract: Michigan Gov Rick Snyder, a Republican business executive who took office in 2011 after a wave of GOP statehouse victories, has sought to avoid partisan strife, a challenge in a relentlessly partisan atmosphere; he is single-mindedly focused on the state's economic woes.
docs.snippet: Gov. Rick Snyder has sought to fix his state’s economy and avoid party-line battles, but in an increasingly partisan era, is that enough?
